I tracked this down to DNS Discovery. It only happens on non-mainnet chains. See, no matter what you do, your client will be discovering eth mainnet nodes, and it causes a timeout to increase until it can try new nodes.

The workaround is to disable using `--nodiscover` and telling your server to use a bootnode(s) using `--bootnodes`

This does not work: `--discovery.dns=""` because this was copied from upstream `go-ethereum,` and erigon has added a discover layer that completely ignores that setting.

I had a fix for this but backed it out with a different solution for the chain I am working on. If I get some time this week, I'll re-implement it again and then send in a PR.

cc: @AlexeyAkhunov @AskAlexSharov

@bretep maybe one question, why this issue didn't occur before? if the client always discovering eth mainnet nodes, why it didn't timeout before but now it is?

Did you add the `--bootnodes` and add a bootnode? If not, then it will just hang like before.

Re: why did this not happen before? The question I have is, "when is before?"

I started a sync on three nodes with trace logging enabled; each node progressed at its own rate, and some got much further than the others before this problem manifested. They were blocked from discovering more clients because of all the failures; after the back-off period, they began discovery again. This happened many times until they could get a node that was the blockchain they were currently syncing and not mainnet. 

Mixing mainnet nodes (via DNS discovery) with the bootnodes from other chains makes the sync behavior unpredictable. 

This explains why restarting or leaving it trying to sync for weeks fixes the issues.

Rewinding is a red herring fix.
